Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: A new furniture order comes in, and the carpenter should estimate material requirements and order supplies as needed
Story: I stare at the overflowing laundry basket, the colors and whites tangled together, a silent reminder that my family will need clean clothes for tomorrow’s school and work. My husband left a note on the fridge: “Can you handle the laundry today? Kids need uniforms.” I nod to myself, feeling the weight of the expectation. But my phone buzzes—a new message from a client. They want a custom bookshelf, and they need an estimate by the end of the day. I glance at my workbench, scattered with sketches and wood samples, and my mind races through measurements, material lists, and supplier contacts. I know if I don’t get the order in today, the project will be delayed, and my reputation as a reliable carpenter will take a hit. My heart pounds as I stand in the hallway, torn between the hum of the washing machine and the call of my workshop. Both roles demand my attention, both are urgent, and I feel the pressure mounting as I try to decide which responsibility to tackle first.
